titleStmt.title: The O'Connell Centenary Committee., More Extraordinary Scenes, The Irish Times, Wednesday 24 November 1875

availability.licence: This metadata is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International (CC BY-NC 4.0).

analytic.title: The O'Connell Centenary Committee., More Extraordinary Scenes

body.p: Mr Parnell assured them that he came there anxious and determined if possible to act in the spirit indicated by the very rev gentleman, but at the outset they found themselves, he regretted to say, in a difficulty, about the minutes. They were imperfect, inasmuch as they did not contain a report of the proceedings that took place after his lordship left the chair.
Mr Parnell - Your lordship, in your letter to the papers gave as one of the reasons that I was not qualified to act as chairman, that I was not a subscriber.
The Lord Mayor said he believed he stated that he had not seen in any of the printed lists the name of Mr Parnell.

Mr Parnell - I understood your lordship correctly. Now, I did not subscribe to the Mansion House fund. I did intend to do so, but circumstances arose which prevented me. To these circumstances I shall not refer unless called upon. I did not subscribe to your Lordship's fund; but I did subscribe to two public bodies in Meath -
Mr Parnell - Who took part in the procession? I subscribed to another -
The Lord Mayor - Have you any objection to state what these bodies were?

Mr Parnell - Not the least. I subscribed to the bakers of Navan, and I subscribed to the Drogheda band for uniforms to enable them to appear respectably in the procession; and I subscribed to the Amnesty Association in Dublin. (Hear, hear.) I subscribed to these three bodies. I looked upon the procession as the great feature of the celebration. (Hear, hear.) Even the English press were compelled to admit that the Irish were a people who could govern themselves. There were no policemen, no soldiers - every man his own governor and his own ruler. As to the circular all I can say is that I never got it, and under these circumstances I may assume it was never sent. (Hear, hear.)
Mr Parnell - May I ask when Mr Keegan saw this circular addressed to me?

Mr Parnell - And I was not a member of Parliament for more than a month after that. (Laughter). I never got the circular. I utterly deny that you can alter the constitution of the committee as defined by the Conference, any more than the President of the United States could alter the constitution of that amnesty or Queen Victoria could alter the British Constitution. (Hear, hear.) Mr Parnell condemned the conduct of the Lord Mayor on leaving the chair, and as to his own eligibility, said he had attended there without being objected to on two previous occasions, and had then exercised the privilege of speaking. They wanted to settle these matters quietly, but they had a duty to perform. They must see that the money was spent legally and properly, and in accordance with the wishes of the country. (Hear, hear.)
